Award.AwardTitle: Mechanistic Investigations of Olefin Polymerizations and Selective Oligomerizations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry program supports work by Professor Lawrence R. Sita at the University of Maryland, College Park to investigate mechanisms for the coordination polymerization and selective oligomerization of 1-alkenes as mediated by molecularly-well-defined transition metal complexes. Novel dynamic and reversible bimolecular processes that are competitive with first-order chain-growth propagation are being identified and established as mechanistic control points by which the production of a near continuum of different polyolefin grades between two limiting materials can be accomplished using only a single catalyst. When combined with living coordination chain-transfer polymerization, it is anticipated that practical commercial volumes of these new polyolefin materials can be realized. The supported work further provides a critical vehicle through which outreach activities will be conducted to educate the general public regarding the current needs, limitations, and impact of the global polyolefins industry and related research. Students conducting the studies receive training in both fundamental and practical apsects of chemistry and will be well prepared to enter the workforce.

Civilization and the quality of life as we know it is wholly dependent upon "plastic" materials prepared through the coordination polymerization of ethene, propene, and higher 1-alkene using catalysts that are largely discovered in empirical fashion. Detailed investigations of mechanistic processes that govern these catalysts can provide new and transformational strategies by which the range of plastic materials can be greatly increased while dramatically reducing the research and development cycle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant, CHE-0848293, provided support for research with the specific goal of developing new catalysts and polymerization processes by which fundamental new classess of commercially-relevant polyolefin-based materials can be produced on the industrial scale in efficient and economical fashion. The specific aim of the coordination polymerization research is to identify new intra- and intermolecular dynamic, fast and reversible, processes that are competitive with chain growth propagation and that can be brought under external control as a means by which to significantly expand the structural, microstructural and (copolymer) compositional ranges of precision polyolefins of narrow polydispersity and tunable molecular weights.  Results obtained from this research have been presented in 12 publications in international journals and three new non-provisional patent applications and one issued patent.  A major discovery of the research program led to the development of the concept and demonstration of ternary living coordinative chain transfer polymerization and the resulting publication as cited as both a News of the Week story and as a 2010 Chemistry Highlight by Chemical & Engineering News.  In addition a cover story featuring this NSF-funded research appeared in the Association of University Technology Managers (AUTM) 2010 AUTM Better World Report that has been globally distributed.  

 

 

 

 

The supported research program has also advanced human resources  development and broader impacts to society of the United States, including  contributing to an increase in the number of PhD scientists from underrepresented groups and to economic development through new patents covering commercially-relevant technologies.   


Last Modified: 06/18/2012
Modified by: Lawrence R Sita

Results obtained from this research have been presented in 12 publications in international journals and three new non-provisional patent applications and one issued patent. A major discovery of the research program led to the development of the concept and demonstration of ternary living coordinative chain transfer polymerization and the resulting publication as cited as both a News of the Week story and as a 2010 Chemistry Highlight by Chemical & Engineering News.
